article:
Chunk # 0.
Molecular Conductors from Neutral-Radical Charge-Transfer Salts: Preparation and Characterization of an Iodine-Doped Hexagonal Phase of 1,2,3,5-Dithiadazolyl ([HCN2S2]*)

C D Bryan, A W Cordes, R C Haddon, R G Hicks, D K Kennepohl, C D MacKinnon, R T Oakley, T T M Palstra, A S Perel, S R Scott, L F Schneemeyer, J V Waszczak

Abstract published in _Advance ACS Abstracts_, January 15, 1944 (1) (a) University of Arkansas (b) AT&T Bell Laboratories (c) University of Guelph (2) (See, for example: (a) Garito, A F Heeger, A J _Acc Chem Res._ 1974; 7, 23, 10-7, 18-20, 1974 23) D K Kennepohl, C D MacKinnon, R T Oakley, T T M Palstra, A S Perel, S R Scott, L F Schneemeyer, J V Waszczak

# Abstract

Sublimation of 1,2,3,5-dithiadazolyl _in vacuo_ affords a triclinic phase of the dimer [HCN2S2]2 The crystals belong to the space group \(P\)1, \(a\) = 6.816(3), \(b\) = 13.940(2), \(c\) = 14.403(3) A, \(a\) = 116.830(14), \(b\) = 98.64(3), \(g\) = 99.18(3)deg, FW = 212.4 (4 for [HCN2S2]2T2N2)0.40.2 \(Z\) = 6 The crystal structure consists of stacked dimers, with three dimers per asymmetric unit Pairs of asymmetric units, related by an inversion center, generate a pinwheel motif consisting of six dimers The columnar structure associated with these pinwheels forms close-packed sets of "molecular tubes" Combination of the radical in the presence of iodine in the mole ratio (HCN2S2:1 = 5:1) yields an iodine-doped hexagonal phase of composition [HCN2S2]2[1]1 Crystals of this material belong to the space group \(P\)61, \(a\) = \(b\) = 14.132(16), \(c\) = 3.352(5) A, FW = 128.20, \(Z\) = 6 The crystal structure consists of sixfold pinwheels in which the now evenly spaced HCN2S2 rings form a spiral about the 61 axis The iodine atoms lie within the columnar cavity of the pinwheels in a disordered array wrapped tightly about the sixfold screw axis The single-crystal conductivity of the doped material is 15 S cm-1 at room temperature Raman spectroscopic and magnetic susceptibility measurements on the doped material are reported 
## Introduction

The most common method for the synthesis of organic conductors involves the oxidation or reduction of a closed-shell molecule to generate a mixed-valence or charge-transfer salt Donors such as tetrathiafulvalene (TTF), tetramethyltetrasel-enafulvalene (TMTSF), and BEDT-TTF have found wide application,2 and acceptors like tetracyanoquinodimethane (TCNQ) and, more recently, C60 have also been pursued.3 We have been interested in an alternative approach, namely the development of materials based on building blocks consisting of neutral _p_-radicals, in which the requirement for a partially filled energy band is inherently fulfilled Within this context we have considered several variants4 of the originally proposed phenanyl framework5 and have focused on derivatives of 1,2,3,5-dithiadazolyl and 1,2,3,5-diiselanadiazolyl.6 Our intent has been to generate crystal structures consisting of one-dimensional stacks or columns, and for several derivatives the desired stacking arrangement has been achieved.7 By definition, however, a one-dimensional stack of radicals is formally associated with a half-filled energy band and is susceptible to a charge density wave (CDW) driven or Peierls instability To date we have attempted to stabilize the metallic state by the application of pressure and by preparing compounds in which two- and three-dimensional interactions are enhanced Several small band gap semiconductors have been characterized.7

An alternative approach to the design of conductive materials based on neutral radicals involves p-type doping of the energy band away from the half-filled level associated with the neutral state We have recently communicated that conductive materials can be generated in this way The bifunctional radical [1,4-(S2N2-C)C6H4(CN2S2)],8 for example, reacts with iodine to form the charge-transfer salt [1,4-(S2N2-C)C6H4(CN2S2)][1].9 The solid-state packing of the molecular units in this salt (space group _Inmm_) is, however, quite different from that observed in the parent dimer [1,4-(S2N2-C)C6H4(CN2S2)]2 (space group \(P\)2/_n_) We now report an example of a dithiadazolyl crystal structure which accepts iodine into the lattice without major changes This discovery evolved from our recent study of the prototypal 1,2,3,5-dithiadiazolyl [HCN2S2]* (1).10 The crystal structure reported for the radical dimer [HCN2S2]* (2) was monoclinic, space group \(P2_{1}/c\), and consisted of stacked columns of dimers, with three dimers in the asymmetric unit We have now identified a triclinic phase, space group \(P\bar{1}\), which also consists of stacked dimers, with three dimers in the asymmetric unit By contrast, however, this second phase exhibits an unusual tubular structure, e.g., 3, reminiscent of the hexagonal phase of urea Since urea is known to form inclusion compounds with many small molecules,11 it occurred to us that host/guest complexes could also be prepared based on this new phase for [HCN2S2]2 We have found that cosublimation of 1 and iodine produces a doped phase, with exact hexagonal symmetry, based on the original triclinic lattice
summary: Revised Summary (Iteration 3): Molecular conductors, specifically neutral-radical charge-transfer salts, have been extensively studied by researchers from the University of Arkansas, AT&T Bell Laboratories, University of Guelph, and other institutions. These salts exhibit various crystal phases, including the hexagonal and triclinic phases. The crystal structures of these materials consist of stacked dimers and columnar structures, with iodine atoms residing within the columnar cavity. The conductivity of the doped material has been demonstrated in single-crystal form at room temperature, as measured by Raman spectroscopy and magnetic susceptibility. The synthesis of organic conductors involves oxidation or reduction reactions, utilizing donors like tetrathiafulvalene (TTF) and acceptors such as tetracyanoquinodimethane (TCNQ) and C60. These materials can stabilize the metallic state under pressure and exhibit charge density wave (CDW) phenomena. Crystal packing plays a crucial role in the conductivity of these charge-transfer salts, and their crystal structures can be modified through sublimation or inclusion of other compounds.

article:
Chunk # 1.
Herein we describe the preparation and crystal structures of both the triclinic and doped hexagonal phases and report the magnetic and conductivity characteristics of the doped material 
## Results

### Preparation and Doping of Triclinic [HCN2S2]2 
In our earlier report of the characterization of the monoclinic phase of [HCN2S2]2, we noted that the conditions for crystal growth involved sublimation of the radical under an atmosphere of argon In practice the samples were heated in sealed tubes subjected to a gentle temperature gradient from 70 to 20 degC An alternative method for crystal growth, indeed the one most commonly used for bulk sample purification, involves sublimation of the radical _in vacuo_ (typically 10-2 Torr) Under these pressure conditions a temperature gradient of 30-0 degC (ice/water) is usually employed The crystalline needles so obtained are thinner, and more fibrous, than those obtained by the 1-atm sublimation, and structural (X-ray) characterization required the selection and preliminary analysis of many crystals The samples were usually collected after flooding the sublimer with dry nitrogen, and this could account for the inclusion of trace quantities of what may be dinitrogen (_vide infra_) into the lattice 
The reactions of 1 with iodine were carried out in sealed, evacuated tubes The reagents (either the monoclinic or the triclinic phase of the dimer 2) were vaporized along a temperature gradient from 70 to 30 degC, and the tube was then reversed and the sublimate re-evaporated After several (at least six) passes, a relatively homogeneous selection of lustrous silver-black hexagonal crystals was produced In early experiments the two reagents were introduced in a ratio of 6:1 ([HCN2S2]:I), but after repeated chemical and crystallographic analyses of the best samples (see Experimental Section), which established the level of loading of iodine in the doped material, the stoichiometry of mixing was eventually adjusted to 5:1 The crystals so obtained were harvested in an argon-filled drybox Although they are relatively air-sensitive, losing their luster after 2-3 min of exposure, they could be handled for shorter periods in dry air (for X-ray crystal mounting purposes) 
### Crystal Structure of Triclinic [HCN2S2]2 
Atomic coordinates for the triclinic phase of [HCN2S2]2 are provided in Table 1, and a summary of pertinent bond lengths is presented in Table 2 Like the case of monoclinic phase, the structure of the triclinic phase also consists of stacked dimers, with three dimers in the asymmetric unit Figure 1 illustrates the stacking of the asymmetric units in the \(x\) direction The intradimer-S- distance (mean 3.103 A), and the interdimer S-*-S contacts along the stack (mean 3.786 A) are comparable to those seen in the monoclinic structure The internal ring bonds and angles are also very similar 
The major difference between the two phases can be appreciated when the two structures are viewed down the stacking direction In both the triclinic and monoclinic phases the stacks associate into groups of six, each comprised of two centrosymmetrically related sets of the three crystallographically independent dimers In the monoclinic crystal these six-stack groups have an irregular cross section which represents efficient space filling.10 By contrast the six-stack groups of the triclinic phase resemble a pinwheel or "mercry-go-round" motif (Figure 2) The three-dimensional structure thus consists of a series of molecular tubes, inside of which there is a strikingly large cavity
summary:
Summary (Iteration 7):
Crystal structures of triclinic and doped hexagonal phases of [HCN2S2]2 were prepared and characterized. The doped material exhibited magnetic and conductivity characteristics. The triclinic phase was obtained through sublimation under an argon atmosphere, involving crystal growth in sealed tubes with a temperature gradient from 70 to 20 degC. The crystals obtained under vacuum conditions had a thinner and more fibrous morphology. X-ray crystallographic analyses were conducted to determine atomic coordinates, bond lengths, and angles. The triclinic phase showed stacked dimers with comparable bonds to the monoclinic phase. It formed a pinwheel or "mercy-go-round" motif in its three-dimensional structure, consisting of molecular tubes with a strikingly large cavity. The crystal growth of the triclinic phase involved loading in air-sensitive conditions and resulted in efficient space filling. The lustrous silver-black hexagonal crystals of the doped material were analyzed for their structural properties. The intradimer-S- distance and interdimer S-*-S contacts were observed in the crystal structures, and the crystals were used for X-ray crystal mounting purposes. The preparation of crystalline needles involved the use of iodine and sublimation under vacuum conditions (10-2 Torr). The crystal structures revealed the presence of stacks with internal ring bonds, and the stacking of asymmetric units was discussed in our earlier report. Stoichiometry was adjusted to a 5:1 ratio of [HCN2S2]2 to iodine during the crystal growth process.

summary: Revised Summary: The triclinic [HCN2S2]2*[N2]0a4 structure features molecular tubes arranged in a close-packed, near-hexagonal crystal symmetry. Two centers of electron density within the tubes were modeled by nitrogen atoms. The size of the columnar cavity, with an average diameter of 7.43 A, is estimated based on the perpendicular distances of the innermost sulfur atoms of the dimer units to the I axis. The crystal structure exhibits a near-hexagonal symmetry.

summary: The columnar cavity size is estimated based on the perpendicular distances of the innermost sulfur atoms of the three dimer units to the I axis. The range of these distances is from 3.309 A (S7) to 3.985 A (S4), with an average of 3.715 A. Consequently, the average diameter of the cavity is 7.43 A. The molecular tubes are arranged in a close-packed configuration, resembling a near-hexagonal crystal symmetry. Within these tubes, two centers of electron density were identified and represented by nitrogen atoms with fractional occupancies.

summary: The columnar cavity size is estimated based on the distances of the innermost sulfur atoms to the I axis, ranging from 3.309 A (S7) to 3.985 A (S4) with an average of 3.715 A. The average diameter of the cavity is 7.43 A. The molecular tubes form a close-packed arrangement with near-hexagonal crystal symmetry. Nitrogen atoms with fractional occupancies model two centers of electron density within the tubes (see Experimental Section).

summary: The columnar cavity size is estimated based on the perpendicular distances of the outermost sulfur atoms of the three dimer units to the I axis. The range of these distances is from 3.309 A (for S7) to 3.985 A (S4), with an average of 3.715 A. The average diameter of the cavity is 7.43 A. The molecular tubes are arranged in a close-packed configuration, resembling a near-hexagonal crystal symmetry. Two centers of electron density, represented by nitrogen atoms with fractional occupancies, were found within these tubes.

article:
Chunk # 6.
The size of the columnar cavity can be estimated in terms of the perpendicular distances of the outermost sulfur atoms of the three dimer units to the I axis; these values range from a low of 3.309 A (for S7) to a high of 3.985 A (S4) with an average of 3.715 A; the average diameter of the cavity is thus 7.43 A The molecular tubes are locked in a close-packed arrangement, e.g., 3, which constitutes a near-hexagonal crystal symmetry Three series of close S- - S structure two centers of electron density were located within these tubes and were eventually modeled by nitrogen atoms with fractional occupancies (see Experimental Section) The size of the columnar cavity can be estimated in terms of the perpendicular distances of the outermost sulfur atoms of the three dimer units to the I axis; these values range from a low 3.3feature of the doped structure is the molecular repeat distance, the unit cell dimension \(a\), which is now 3.352(S) A, i.e., the heterocyclic HCN_S_2 rings are uniformly spaced The internal diameter of the tubes, defined as twice the distance from the innermost sulfur (S2) to the 61 axis, is 7.40 A, i.e., very similar to that observed in the undoped structure 
Iodine atoms are incorporated into the columnar cavities and are disordered The disorder model presented here essentially distributes the electron density of the iodines evenly along the cavities The 61 symmetry, the 3.352 A cell repeat, and the sites used give a tight spiral of iodine positions which are separated by about 0.5 A both horizontally and vertically, with a spiral diameter of less than 1 A Many crystals of this material were examined, and a total of four data sets were collected The data and the iodine occupancies presented here are from the best refinement In the other data sets the occupancy varied from a low of 0.18 to a high of 0.22 The reported value corresponds to an iodine loading of 1.1 iodines per six [HCN_S_2] units and is in good agreement with the results of repeated chemical analyses on different samples 
### Raman Spectra of [HCN_S_2] and [HCN_S_2][I]1.1

In order to probe further the structural changes associated with iodine incorporation, we have recorded the Raman spectra of the parent compound [HCN_S_2]2 (triclinic phase) and its iodine-doped derivative [HCN_S_2]2[I]1.1 (Figure 5) In the undoped material, clear, well-resolved bands are observed throughout the entire vibrational region; a complete listing of the observed Raman bands is provided in the Experimental Section.12 For the doped material, however, scattering associated with iodine dominates the spectrum, and only two broad bands, at 107 and 148 cm-1, are observed In the undoped compound the most notable feature, within the present context, is the strong, broad band centered at 124 cm-1 In our recent analysis of the gas-phase vibrational spectrum of [HCN_S_2]2 (1), we determined (from _ab initio_ frequency calculations) that the lowest vibrational modes should occur near 475 cm-1 (A1 symmetry) and 219 cm-1 (A2 symmetry).10 Of these, the former, which is loosely associated with the internal S-S bond, is predicted to be very strong in the Raman spectrum; the latter is predicted to be vanishingly weak.13 Dimerization of the radical perturbs the gas-phase structure only slightly,10 from which we conclude that the observed band at 463 cm-1 in triclinic [HCN_S_2]2 is still largely an intra-annular S-S stretch Because there are no predicted Raman-active intra-annular modes below the 400-cm-1 region, we assign the band centered at 124 cm-1 to interannular S- -S vibrations which are broadened by lattice coupling effects We do not, however, venture beyond qualitative assignments of the two Raman bands in [HCN_S_2]2[I]1.1 One or both may involve the internal stretching modes of a linear polyiodide species.14 In benzophenone/iodine/potassium iodide (BIKI),15 for example, the disordered iodines also occupy a hexagonal cavity,16 and the resonance Raman spectrum displays broad bands at 167 and 108 cm-1.17 However, the possibility that weak S - -S or even S - -1 interactions are involved in the present system cannot be discounted 
In spite of these uncertainties surrounding the low-frequency region, we can conclude that at both room (295 K) and low (130 K) temperature there is partial charge transfer from iodine to radical, i.e., the encapsulated iodine is in the form of a polyiodide We refrain, however, from formal assessment of the degree of charge transfer The subtle changes observed on cooling the doped material, i.e., the increase in the intensity of the higher frequency band, may be indicative of a subtle change in charge transfer and may also signal the onset of some association of the rings (see the magnetic measurements below) 
### Magnetic and Conductivity Measurements 
The measured magnetic susceptibility of [HCN_S_2]2[I]1.1 as a function of temperature is shown in Figure 6
summary: The columnar cavity size is estimated based on the distances of the outermost sulfur atoms of the dimer units to the I axis, ranging from 3.309 A to 3.985 A, with an average of 3.715 A. The average diameter of the cavity is 7.43 A. The molecular tubes are arranged in a close-packed near-hexagonal crystal symmetry. Two centers of electron density, modeled by nitrogen atoms, are located within these tubes. The doped structure has a molecular repeat distance of 3.352 A. Iodine atoms are incorporated into the cavities in a disordered manner, distributed evenly along the cavities. The iodine loading corresponds to 1.1 iodines per six [HCN_S_2] units. Raman spectra of the undoped and iodine-doped compounds show significant changes, with iodine dominating the spectrum in the doped compound. The observed bands in the undoped compound suggest interannular S-S vibrations. The doped compound exhibits partial charge transfer from iodine to the radical. Magnetic susceptibility measurements of the doped compound show temperature dependence.

article:
Chunk # 7.
As in the case of [1,4-(S_2N2C)-C_H_H_H_C(S_2)]1.3 the concentration of spin-bearing defects is very low (0.01% per molecule), and at low temperatures the material is diamagnetic (confirmed by ESR) A pronounced spin susceptibility begins to develop at about 180 K, and the sample paramagnetism continues to increase to the highest temperatures attainable (before sample decomposition) Similar behavior was seen for [1,4-(S_2N2C)C_H_H_C(S_2)]1 [I], except that in that case the rise in susceptibility slowed above room

Figure 4.: Internal rearrangement of columnar cavities in [HCN_S_2]2 occasional by iodine doping The nearly horizontal connectivity lines on the left, and the spiral connectivity lines on the right, are defined in Table 2 
Figure 5.: Raman spectra of triclinic [HCN_S_2]2 (above) and [HCN_S_2]2 (I)1.1 (below) Inserts are magnifications of the 30050cm1 region For the doped material two temperatures are shown: 295 K (solid line) and 130 K (dashed line) The spike near 2800 cm1 in the lower spectrum is of instrumental origin 
temperature.9 Furthermore, the two inflection points seen in the susceptibility of [HCN3S2]6[[1]]1,1 were not apparent in the magnetic study of [1,4-(S2N2C)C6H4(CN3S2)][1] However, two phase transitions were observed by X-ray diffraction and conductivity studies.9 It is therefore possible that the points of inflection seen in the magnetic susceptibility of [HCN3S2]6[[1]]1,1 also correspond to transition(s) between metal and charge density wave (CDW) insulator 
The volatility and air sensitivity of [HCN3S2]6[[1]]1,1 have provided a major barrier to a complete single-crystal conductivity measurement Wires were attached to a number of samples in a He-filled drybox, but the contact and sample degradation were sufficiently rapid to preclude variable-temperature studies Two samples were measured in a drybox, by using gold paint to attach the leads, and in each case the conductivity was found to be 15 S cm-1 
## Summary

In addition to the tetrathiafulvalene-based donors already noted,2 many other closed-shell molecules, e.g., aromatic hydrocarbons and amines, form conductive charge-transfer compounds with iodine.14,18,19 In many of these complexes, the crystal structures exhibit linear arrays of disordered iodines, in the form of a complex polyiodide, encapsulated in a channel-like cavity within the host molecular lattice The present system, however, represents only the second example of a highly conductive material to be generated by the p-type doping of a neutral radical It is, moreover, a rare example of a molecular conductor which, like C60, retains its basic structure during the doping process (the dopant fills a structural void) In the present case the combination of stoichiometry, cell repeat distance, and Raman spectroscopic data for [HCN3S2]6[[1]]1, collectively indicate the presence of a polyiodide in the columnar cavity Although we cannot fix the degree of charge transfer with any exactitude, the stoichiometry of the material requires that the oxidation state of each HCN3S2 ring in the doped compound be less than +0.18.20

The sensitivity of the present compound to oxygen and moisture has precluded a detailed analysis of its low-temperature structure and transport properties From the similarity of the magnetic behavior of [HCN3S2]6[[1]]1,1 and [1,4-(S2N2C)C6H4(CN3S2)]-[1],9 we are nonetheless able to conclude that in the former, as in the latter, a CDW-driven instability sets in below 2K Most importantly, however, the observation of a uniformly spaced structure and high conductivity for [HCN3S2]6[[1]]1,1 confirms that a small degree of p-type doping of neutral dithiadiaxyls away from their neutral oxidation state (a half-filled energy band) can generate a room-temperature molecular conductor 
Starting Materials and General Procedures iodine was obtained commercially (Fisher) and used as received 1,2,3,5-Dithiazolyl was prepared as described previously.10 Sublimitations and gas-phase reactions were performed in an ATS Series 3210 three-zone tube furnace, linked to a Series 1400 temperature-control system Elemental analyses were performed by MHV Laboratories, Phoenix, AZ 
## Triclinic Phase of [HCN3S2] 
Sublimation of either the triclinic phase of 2 described here or the monoclinic phase reported earlier affords vapors of the radical 1 In crystal growth experiments the phase of the starting dimer was thus immaterial Crystals of the triclinic phase were typically (but not exclusively) obtained by sublimation of the crude dimer (prepared as described previously) in a put sublimer immersed in a warm (30-35 degC) water bath and evacuated to a static vacuum of about 10-7 Torr The sublimate was collected on an ice/water-cooled finger over a period of 24 h In contrast to the crystals of the monoclinic phase, which are well-faceted, the thin, black needles of the triclinic phase are fibrous and prone to splitting Cleaving the crystals, for mounting purposes, was therefore difficult 
### Iodine-Doped Hexagonal Phase 
Crystals of either phase of dimer 2 (usually about 0.5 g), along with iodine (in a ratio of HCN3S2C1 of 5:1), were sealed at 10-3 Torr in a 25 x 250 mm Pyrex tube which was placed in a tube furnace ramped from 70 to 30 degC
summary:
- The concentration of spin-bearing defects in [1,4-(S2N2C)-CHHHCS2]1.3 is very low (0.01% per molecule).
- At low temperatures, the material is diamagnetic, but a pronounced spin susceptibility develops at around 180 K.
- [1,4-(S2N2C)CHHC(S2)]1 shows similar behavior, but the rise in susceptibility slows above room temperature.
- The columnar cavities in [HCNS2]2 undergo internal rearrangement when iodine is doped.
- Raman spectra of triclinic [HCNS2]2 and [HCNS2]2(I)1.1 show differences, with a spike near 2800 cm-1 in the doped material.
- [HCN3S2]6[[1]]1 exhibits two phase transitions observed by X-ray diffraction and conductivity studies.
- The volatility and air sensitivity of [HCN3S2]6[[1]]1 hinder complete single-crystal conductivity measurements.
- Many closed-shell molecules can form conductive charge-transfer compounds with iodine, including aromatic hydrocarbons and amines.
- [HCN3S2]6[[1]]1 is a highly conductive material generated by p-type doping of a neutral radical.
- The compound is sensitive to oxygen and moisture, limiting analysis of its low-temperature structure and transport properties.
- [HCN3S2]6[[1]]1 and [1,4-(S2N2C)C6H4(CN3S2)][1] exhibit similar magnetic behavior, suggesting a CDW-driven instability below 2K.
- A small degree of p-type doping of neutral dithiadiaxyls can generate a room-temperature molecular conductor.
- The triclinic phase of [HCN3S2] can be obtained by sublimation and is prone to splitting.
- Crystals of dimer 2 along with iodine in a specific ratio can be sealed to create the iodine-doped hexagonal phase.

summary:
**Iteration 6:**
Revised Summary: The material undergoes a sublimation cycle in glass tubes, with the reagents vaporizing and condensing. It forms long, silver-black rods with well-faceted, hexagonal faces. The crystals are air- and heat-sensitive but can be handled briefly in dry air for X-ray mounting. X-ray crystallography and elemental analyses establish the elemental composition. X-ray measurements use monochromated M6 Ka radiation and are conducted on an ENRAF-Nonics CAD-4 diffractometer. The crystals are sealed in epoxy and glass tubes during data collection. The crystal structures are solved using direct methods/SHELX and refined by full-matrix least squares. The triclinic and monoclinic phases of the crystals exhibit twinning. Crystallographic data, including structural parameters, occupancy factors, and isotropic displacement parameters, are collected and analyzed. Nitrogen atoms and N2 molecules are present in the material, with the inclusion of these atoms improving the refinement. The iodine fragments in the material are refined with isotropic displacement parameters and occupancy factors. The high final R-value is attributed to twinning and the inability to accurately model the disorder of the iodine channel. Magnetic susceptibility is studied as a function of temperature. The reproducibility of the iodine content is investigated, and the presence of dimer units and radical units is confirmed. The crystal growth process is influenced by homogeneity and doping.

Inverted the tube and repeated the sublimation cycle
Material's elemental composition established by X-ray crystallography and elemental analyses
X-ray data collected on an ENRAF-Nonics CAD-4 diffractometer with monochromated M6 Ka radiation
Crystals sealed in epoxy and glass tubes
Structures solved using direct methods/SHELX and refined by full-matrix least squares
Table 4 provides a summary of crystallographic data
Magnetic susceptibility of [HCN3S2]6 as a function of temperature
Persistent difference map peaks in the columnar cavity treated as partial nitrogen atoms
Near-hexagonal structure not consistent with hexagonal symmetry
Twinning problems and the desire to check the reproducibility of the iodine content
Four different crystals used for the refinement
Iodine fragments refined alternately with isotropic displacement parameters and occupancy factors
High final R-value attributed to twinning and inadequacies of the structure to model the disorder of the iodine channel

article:
Chunk # 9.

## Magnetic Measurements

The magnetic susceptibility of [HCN3]6e[I1,1] was measured from 4.2 to about 400 K by using the Faraday technique Details of the apparatus have been previously described.22

## Raman Spectra

Raman spectra were recorded on a Bruker FRA 106 FT Raman module interfaced to a Bruker IFS 66 FTIR bench For the undoped material, data was accumulated for 200 scans with a laser power of 250 mW The full spectrum of the undoped material exhibits bands at 3029(m), 1482(w), 1372(w), 1245(w), 779(s), 742(w), 501(w), 462-(s), and 124(vs) cm-1 The same number of scans (200) was used for the doped compound (at both 295 and 130 K); slight sample heating (blackbody radiation) required that a lower laser power (70 mW) be used 
## Acknowledgment

Financial support at Guelph was provided by the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada (NSERC) and at Arkansas by the National Science Foundation (EPSCOR program) C.D.B acknowledges a DOE/ASTA Traineeship We thank Ms Janice Hellman, of Bruker Spectrospin (Canada) Ltd., for assistance in obtaining the Raman spectra 
## Supplementary Material Available

Tables of crystal data, structure solution and refinement, atomic coordinates, bond lengths and angles, and anisotropic thermal parameters, and ORTEP drawings (7 pages) This material is contained in many libraries on microfiche, immediately follows this article in the microfilm versionoft the journal, and can be orderedfrom the ACS; see any current masthead page for ordering information.
summary: Magnetic susceptibility of [HCN3]6e[I1,1] was measured using the Faraday technique from 4.2 to 400 K. Raman spectra were recorded on a Bruker FRA 106 FT Raman module. The undoped material exhibited bands at 3029(m), 1482(w), 1372(w), 1245(w), 779(s), 742(w), 501(w), 462-(s), and 124(vs) cm-1. Financial support was provided by NSERC and the National Science Foundation. Supplementary material is available in libraries and can be ordered from the ACS.
